metadata.title: CYB-392 - Add logger to the API
CYB-392 - Add logger to the API

__data__.text:
##  Relevant data

Logging gives us visibility and helps us diagnose problems in production. We
can also in future push the logs to a central service for easy searching.

##  Background

Logs in Nodejs should not have console logs scattered everywhere. We should
employ a logging library that allows us a bit more control over what levels we
need in different environments. For example, we might want to debug mode in
the dev environment and only errors in the production environment to reduce
the chattiness.

We have two options, the options are low risk because the risk to change is
going to be mitigated by an abstraction (wrapper/interface), we can easily
swap out libraries. The most popular two are Pino and Winston.

Terms:

Transportation - different mechanisms of logging to various types like files,
API, console..etc

##  Options Considered

|

 **Option 1 - Pino**

|

 **Option 2 - Winston**  
  
---|---|---  
  
 **Description**

|

https://github.com/pinojs/pino

|

https://github.com/winstonjs/winston  
  
**Pros and cons**

|

actively maintained 11K stars

support transportation

9 days release fequency

4 maintainers

83 issues

|

actively maintained 20K stars

support transportation

8 maintainers

every 2 months release

​​ 462 issues  
  
 **Estimated cost**

|

Greenlow

|

Greenlow  
  
##  Outcome

 **Option 1 is the recommended solution as it has fewer issues and the release
frequency is high which would. This would deem the least risk.**

Option 2 whilst more popular and more mature with more stars, any issues that
we come across will have to wait 2 months for a release and since they have a
big backlog it might not be fixed and we will need to fork and patch it
ourselves. The fork risk is a bit higher than option 1.

**Pre-requisites**

  * Git 

  * Recommended IDE – Visual Studio Code 

  * npm version 8.5.5 

  * NodeJS version 16.15.0(install using nvm if you have other versions of NodeJS installed on your device. will be explained in the next section).

  * MySQL workbench latest version (link - _MySQL :: Download MySQL Workbench_ ). If you have already installed MySQL server including the workbench, then you can continue with it.

  * MongoDB compass latest version (link - _MongoDB Compass Download | MongoDB_ ). If you have already installed MongoDB compass, then you can continue with it.

**Installing NodeJS 16.15.0 using nvm**

  * Download & install nvm(node version manager) application using the following link (link - _Releases · coreybutler/nvm-windows (github.com)_ ).

  * Once nvm is installed, you can install any node version on your device and use them whenever required.

  * Install NodeJS 16.15.0 using the following command in the command prompt.

 **nvm install 16.15.0**

  * Then use the installed version using the below command in the command prompt.

 **nvm use 16.15.0**

  * If NodeJS is installed correctly, following output should be displayed in the command prompt.

**Connecting the MariaDB database using MySQL workbench**

  * Open the MySQL workbench and create a new MySQL connection.

  * In the opened window, enter the following details as depicted in the diagram below and don’t change anything else. Connection name can be anything you prefer.

    * Hostname - cybermitymariadb.mariadb.database.azure.com

    * Username - cybermityadmin@cybermitymariadb

    * Password – Cybermity123 (Insert the password using Store in Vault option)

  * After entering the details, click Test Connection and if everything is configured in the proper way you should get a prompt saying MySQL connection is successfully made. 

  * Then click the OK button in the Setup New Connection window and create the connection with the MariaDB database.

  * You should be able to view the Cybermity MariaDB database tables through the workbench.

**Connecting the MongoDB database using MongoDB compass**

  * Open the MongoDB compass and create a new connection by entering the following URL.

_mongodb+srv://cybermitydev:cybermitydev@cybermitydev.cw0jo.mongodb.net/CybermityDev?retryWrites=true
&w=majority_

  * After entering the above URL, click Save&Connect to connect to the MongoDB database. You should be able to see the database collections as below.

**Git Repositories**

Frontend repository link - https://github.com/kodezorg/cybermity-frontend.git

Backend repository link - https://github.com/kodezorg/cybermity-backend.git

  * Clone the above 2 repositories to a preferred location in your device (if you don’t have access, contact your supervisor to gain access).

  * Once the cloning is completed, contact your supervisor or a team member to obtain the env files for the 2 repositories.

  * Place the relevant env file in the root folder of each repository.

**Running the frontend program**

  * Open the front-end codebase from the root folder using Visual Studio Code.

  * Open a new terminal and run the command **npm install** to install the node modules including the npm packages required to run the front-end program (If npm install fails, run **npm install --force** command).

  * After node modules installation completes, run the program using **npm start** command.

  * On successful run, following interface should be obtained in your web browser.

**Running the backend program**

  * Open the back-end codebase from the root folder using Visual Studio Code.

  * Open a new terminal and run the command **npm install** to install the node modules including the npm packages required to run the back-end program (If npm install fails, run **npm install --force** command).

  * After node modules installation completes, run the program using **npm run dev** command.

  * On successful run, following terminal logs should be obtained.
